The `trekcolors` package provides a collection of color palettes based on Star Trek.

## Installation

You can install the development version of `trekcolors` from GitHub with:

``` r
# install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("leonawicz/trekcolors")
```

## Basic examples

```{r ex1}
library(trekcolors)
library(ggplot2)

trek_pal("starfleet")

trek_pal("lcars_2357")
lcars_pal("2357") # there are some special functions for LCARS colors
```

Preview the `starfleet` and `lcars_2357` palettes.

```{r ex2}
view_trek_pals(c("starfleet", "lcars_2357"))
```

Use these in a couple example plots.

```{r ex3}
p <- ggplot(iris, aes(Sepal.Width, Sepal.Length, color = Species)) + 
  geom_point(size = 2)
p + scale_color_trek() # starfleet is default palette

p <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price, color = clarity)) + 
  geom_point()
p + scale_color_lcars("2357") # equivalent to scale_color_trek("lcars_2357")
```

## Palettes with named colors

The four LCARS palettes that have a year in their series name are special in that these official standard LCARS colors have formal names.

```{r ex4}
# lcars_pals() # print list of LCARS palettes

lcars_colors() # full set of unique names across the four palettes

lcars_2357() # specific color series; also 2369, 2375, 2379

lcars_2357("lilac", "mariner") # select by name
```

## Custom palettes

In addition to these and all the other predefined palettes, custom palettes can be constructed using official LCARS color names. This is like `colorRampPalette` but with the ability to recognize official LCARS color names. This functionality is also leveraged by functions like `scale_color_lcars1` and `scale_color_lcars2` when making sequential and divergent palettes based on specific LCARS colors for use with ggplot.

```{r ex5}
lcars_canary_egg <- lcars_colors_pal(c("pale-canary", "eggplant"))
lcars_canary_egg(8)

p <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(clarity, fill = clarity)) + geom_bar()
p + scale_fill_lcars2("pale-canary", "eggplant")
# p + scale_fill_manual(values = lcars_canary_egg(8)) # equivalent
```

## All predefined palettes

```{r ex6, fig.width=6, fig.height=8}
# See available palette names
trek_pal()

# view all predefined palettes
view_trek_pals()
```
